column2: CHAPTER XXXII.
column3: CHAPTER thirty two.

column2: On the 13th of August we awoke early.
column3: On the thirteenth of August we awoke early.

column2: We were now to begin to adopt a mode of travelling both more expeditious and less fatiguing than hitherto.
column3: We were now to begin to adopt a mode of travelling both more expeditious and less fatiguing than hitherto.

column2: A mast was made of two poles spliced together, a yard was made of a third, a blanket borrowed from our coverings made a tolerable sail. There was no want of cordage for the rigging, and everything was well and firmly made.
column3: A mast was made of two poles spliced together, a yard was made of a third, a blanket borrowed from our coverings made a tolerable sail. There was no want of cordage for the rigging, and everything was well and firmly made.

column2: The provisions, the baggage, the instruments, the guns, and a good quantity of fresh water from the rocks around, all found their proper places on board; and at six the Professor gave the signal to embark. Hans had fitted up a rudder to steer his vessel.
column3: The provisions, the baggage, the instruments, the guns, and a good quantity of fresh water from the rocks around, all found their proper places on board; and at six the Professor gave the signal to embark. Hans had fitted up a rudder to steer his vessel.

column2: He took the tiller, and unmoored; the sail was set, and we were soon afloat.
column3: He took the tiller, and unmoored; the sail was set, and we were soon afloat.

column2: At the moment of leaving the harbour, my uncle, who was tenaciously fond of naming his new discoveries, wanted to give it a name, and proposed mine amongst others.
column3: At the moment of leaving the harbour, my uncle, who was tenaciously fond of naming his new discoveries, wanted to give it a name, and proposed mine amongst others.

column2: But I have a better to propose, I said: "Grauben.
column3: But I have a better to propose, I said: "Grauben.

column2: The wind was from the north-west.
column3: The wind was from the north-west.

column2: We went with it at a high rate of speed.
column3: We went with it at a high rate of speed.

column2: The dense atmosphere acted with great force and impelled us swiftly on.
column3: The dense atmosphere acted with great force and impelled us swiftly on.

column2: At this rate, he said, we shall make thirty leagues in twenty-four hours, and we shall soon come in sight of the opposite shore.
column3: At this rate, he said, we shall make thirty leagues in twenty four hours, and we shall soon come in sight of the opposite shore.

column2: I made no answer, but went and sat forward.
column3: I made no answer, but went and sat forward.

column2: The eastern and western strands spread wide as if to bid us farewell.
column3: The eastern and western strands spread wide as if to bid us farewell.

column2: Before our eyes lay far and wide a vast sea; shadows of great clouds swept heavily over its silver-grey surface; the glistening bluish rays of electric light, here and there reflected by the dancing drops of spray, shot out little sheaves of light from the track we left in our rear.
column3: Before our eyes lay far and wide a vast sea; shadows of great clouds swept heavily over its silver grey surface; the glistening bluish rays of electric light, here and there reflected by the dancing drops of spray, shot out little sheaves of light from the track we left in our rear.

column2: Soon we entirely lost sight of land; no object was left for the eye to judge by, and but for the frothy track of the raft, I might have thought we were standing still.
column3: Soon we entirely lost sight of land; no object was left for the eye to judge by, and but for the frothy track of the raft, I might have thought we were standing still.

column2: I was aware of the great powers of vegetation that characterise these plants, which grow at a depth of twelve thousand feet, reproduce themselves under a pressure of four hundred atmospheres, and sometimes form barriers strong enough to impede the course of a ship.
column3: I was aware of the great powers of vegetation that characterise these plants, which grow at a depth of twelve thousand feet, reproduce themselves under a pressure of four hundred atmospheres, and sometimes form barriers strong enough to impede the course of a ship.

column2: Evening came, and, as on the previous day, I perceived no change in the luminous condition of the air.
column3: Evening came, and, as on the previous day, I perceived no change in the luminous condition of the air.

column2: It was a constant condition, the permanency of which might be relied upon.
column3: It was a constant condition, the permanency of which might be relied upon.

column2: After supper I laid myself down at the foot of the mast, and fell asleep in the midst of fantastic reveries.
column3: After supper I laid myself down at the foot of the mast, and fell asleep in the midst of fantastic reveries.

column2: Hans, keeping fast by the helm, let the raft run on, which, after all, needed no steering, the wind blowing directly aft.
column3: Hans, keeping fast by the helm, let the raft run on, which, after all, needed no steering, the wind blowing directly aft.

column2: I shall therefore reproduce here these daily notes, written, so to speak, as the course of events directed, in order to furnish an exact narrative of our passage.
column3: I shall therefore reproduce here these daily notes, written, so to speak, as the course of events directed, in order to furnish an exact narrative of our passage.

column2: Nothing in sight before us.
column3: Nothing in sight before us.

column2: Intensity of light the same.
column3: Intensity of light the same.

column2: Weather fine; that is to say, that the clouds are flying high, are light, and bathed in a white atmosphere resembling silver in a state of fusion.
column3: Weather fine; that is to say, that the clouds are flying high, are light, and bathed in a white atmosphere resembling silver in a state of fusion.

column2: At noon Hans prepared a hook at the end of a line.
column3: At noon Hans prepared a hook at the end of a line.

column2: He baited it with a small piece of meat and flung it into the sea.
column3: He baited it with a small piece of meat and flung it into the sea.

column2: For two hours nothing was caught.
column3: For two hours nothing was caught.

column2: No, there's a pull at the line.
column3: No, there's a pull at the line.

column2: Hans draws it in and brings out a struggling fish.
column3: Hans draws it in and brings out a struggling fish.

column2: A sturgeon, I cried; "a small sturgeon."
column3: A sturgeon, I cried; "a small sturgeon."

column2: The Professor eyes the creature attentively, and his opinion differs from mine.
column3: The Professor eyes the creature attentively, and his opinion differs from mine.

column2: The head of this fish was flat, but rounded in front, and the anterior part of its body was plated with bony, angular scales; it had no teeth, its pectoral fins were large, and of tail there was none.
column3: The head of this fish was flat, but rounded in front, and the anterior part of its body was plated with bony, angular scales; it had no teeth, its pectoral fins were large, and of tail there was none.

column2: The animal belonged to the same order as the sturgeon, but differed from that fish in many essential particulars.
column3: The animal belonged to the same order as the sturgeon, but differed from that fish in many essential particulars.

column2: This fish belongs to an extinct family, of which only fossil traces are found in the devonian formations.
column3: This fish belongs to an extinct family, of which only fossil traces are found in the devonian formations.

column2: To have in one's possession a living specimen is a happy event for a naturalist."
column3: To have in one's possession a living specimen is a happy event for a naturalist."

column3: But to what family does it belong?

column2: But this one displays a peculiarity confined to all fishes that inhabit subterranean waters.
column3: But this one displays a peculiarity confined to all fishes that inhabit subterranean waters.

column2: I looked: nothing could be more certain.

column2: But supposing it might be a solitary case, we baited afresh, and threw out our line.
column3: But supposing it might be a solitary case, we baited afresh, and threw out our line.

column2: This unhoped-for catch recruited our stock of provisions.
column3: This unhoped for catch recruited our stock of provisions.

column2: Thus it is evident that this sea contains none but species known to us in their fossil state, in which fishes as well as reptiles are the less perfectly and completely organised the farther back their date of creation.
column3: Thus it is evident that this sea contains none but species known to us in their fossil state, in which fishes as well as reptiles are the less perfectly and completely organised the farther back their date of creation.

column2: Perhaps we may yet meet with some of those saurians which science has reconstructed out of a bit of bone or cartilage.
column3: Perhaps we may yet meet with some of those saurians which science has reconstructed out of a bit of bone or cartilage.

column2: I took up the telescope and scanned the whole horizon, and found it everywhere a desert sea.
column3: I took up the telescope and scanned the whole horizon, and found it everywhere a desert sea.

column2: I gaze upward in the air.
column3: I gaze upward in the air.

column2: There are sufficient fish for their support.
column3: There are sufficient fish for their support.

column2: I survey the whole space that stretches overhead; it is as desert as the shore was.
column3: I survey the whole space that stretches overhead; it is as desert as the shore was.

column2: Though awake I fell into a dream.
column3: Though awake I fell into a dream.

column2: I thought I could see floating on the surface of the waters enormous chelonia, pre-adamite tortoises, resembling floating islands.
column3: I thought I could see floating on the surface of the waters enormous chelonia, pre adamite tortoises, resembling floating islands.

column2: Higher up, the protopitheca--the first monkey that appeared on the globe--is climbing up the steep ascents.
column3: Higher up, the protopitheca-the first monkey that appeared on the globe-is climbing up the steep ascents.

column2: In the uppermost regions of the air immense birds, more powerful than the cassowary, and larger than the ostrich, spread their vast breadth of wings and strike with their heads the granite vault that bounds the sky.
column3: In the uppermost regions of the air immense birds, more powerful than the cassowary, and larger than the ostrich, spread their vast breadth of wings and strike with their heads the granite vault that bounds the sky.

column2: I return to the scriptural periods or ages of the world, conventionally called 'days,' long before the appearance of man, when the unfinished world was as yet unfitted for his support.
column3: I return to the scriptural periods or ages of the world, conventionally called 'days,' long before the appearance of man, when the unfinished world was as yet unfitted for his support.

column2: The mammals disappear, then the birds vanish, then the reptiles of the secondary period, and finally the fish, the crustaceans, molluscs, and articulated beings.
column3: The mammals disappear, then the birds vanish, then the reptiles of the secondary period, and finally the fish, the crustaceans, molluscs, and articulated beings.

column2: Then the zoophytes of the transition period also return to nothing.
column3: Then the zoophytes of the transition period also return to nothing.

column2: Vegetation becomes accelerated.
column3: Vegetation becomes accelerated.

column2: And I myself am floating with wild caprice in the midst of this nebulous mass of fourteen hundred thousand times the volume of the earth into which it will one day be condensed, and carried forward amongst the planetary bodies.
column3: And I myself am floating with wild caprice in the midst of this nebulous mass of fourteen hundred thousand times the volume of the earth into which it will one day be condensed, and carried forward amongst the planetary bodies.

column2: My body is no longer firm and terrestrial; it is resolved into its constituent atoms, subtilised, volatilised.
column3: My body is no longer firm and terrestrial; it is resolved into its constituent atoms, subtilised, volatilised.

column2: But is it not a dream?
column3: But is it not a dream?

column2: Whither is it carrying me?
column3: Whither is it carrying me?

column2: My feverish hand has vainly attempted to describe upon paper its strange and wonderful details.
column3: My feverish hand has vainly attempted to describe upon paper its strange and wonderful details.

column2: I have forgotten everything that surrounds me.
column3: I have forgotten everything that surrounds me.

column2: The Professor, the guide, the raft--are all gone out of my ken.
column3: The Professor, the guide, the raft-are all gone out of my ken.

column2: An illusion has laid hold upon me.
column3: An illusion has laid hold upon me.

column2: What is the matter? my uncle breaks in.
column3: What is the matter? my uncle breaks in.

column2: My staring eyes are fixed vacantly upon him.
column3: My staring eyes are fixed vacantly upon him.

column2: At that moment I felt the sinewy hand of Hans seizing me vigorously. But for him, carried away by my dream, I should have thrown myself into the sea.
column3: At that moment I felt the sinewy hand of Hans seizing me vigorously. But for him, carried away by my dream, I should have thrown myself into the sea.

column2: Is he mad? cried the Professor.
column3: Is he mad? cried the Professor.

column2: What is it all about? at last I cried, returning to myself.
column3: What is it all about? at last I cried, returning to myself.

column2: Do you feel ill? my uncle asked.
column3: Do you feel ill? my uncle asked.

column2: Is all going on right?"
